name: Via dei Gordiani
desc:
The choice of Pigneto for shooting Accattone was no coincidence. Villa Gordiani is located a few blocks from via Montecuccoli. It was in this street, far from the traditional studios of Cinecittà, that, a few years earlier, Rossellini had shot his Rome, Open City – in particular the scene of Anna Magnani's death on which Pasolini wrote a poem after seeing the film again after his arrival in Rome, at the “Teatro Nuovo” cinema. The cinematic heritage is coupled with a geographical reference: only some dozen metres separate the shooting locations of the two films.

These days, Pigneto has changed considerably, having become a fashionable neighbourhood, swarming with painters and young artists.

On a miserable road, surrounded by shacks, old cottages, full of tattered little kids, under a furious sun, a sad, desolate bell tolled the knell.
Accattone advanced down the road pummeled by the sun.
He truly was an accattone [beggar], in a singlet with dusty trousers.
Around his neck, there was no longer the thick gold chain.
On his fingers, there was no longer a ring either.
On his wrist there was no longer a bracelet or a watch. Naked as a worm.
He walked down the empty, blinding road, under the bell tolling the knell.
Excerpt from the script
